title: Emergency Damages I
prompt:
Joanne's home insurance covers "Emergency Damages," defined as "loss or damage to the contents of the policyholder's home caused when first responders force an entry into the policyholder's home because of an emergency or perceived emergency involving the policyholder."
Late one night, Joanne hears loud crashing noises coming from another room in her home and knows it is just her two dogs playing together. From her bedroom, she frantically calls the police, who make a forced entry into her home to assess the situation. It turns out that the noises Joanne heard were indeed from her dogs; Joanne just wanted help subduing the dogs. Joanne files a claim with her insurance company for the damage caused by the forced entry.
Considering just how the word "perceived emergency" would be understood by ordinary speakers of English, Is Joanne covered by the insurance?? Yes or No? Final answer is:
output_text:
Yes! I believe it is appropriate to interpret the definition of "emergency" as being both a sudden and unexpected event that prevents someone from leaving their home, and may involve a situation that would not be expected or known about prior to the occurrence of the event. However, in this case, the police were there to deal with an emergency involving the policyholder. Is this the right interpretation?
Here are some of the ways that the court interpreted the word "perceived" when it comes to emergency:
A court will give a broad definition of emergency if it is necessary for a lawsuit to proceed.
A court will look at the circumstances of the claimant at the time of the emergency and use its common sense to determine what level of urgency the claimant felt at the time.
A court will look at the circumstances of the claimant at the time of the emergency and consider whether the claimant took reasonable steps to avoid the emergency or caused it to occur.
A court will look at the circumstances of the claimant at the time of the emergency and consider whether the claimant's conduct was careless.
A court will look at the circumstances of the claimant at the time of the emergency and consider whether the claimant was negligent.
In determining whether the emergency was perceived by the claimant, a court will look at the claimant's actual or constructive knowledge, which is the knowledge the claimant should have had.
A court will look at the circumstances of the claimant at the time of the emergency and consider whether the claimant was negligent.
In the case of Joan's insurance claim, I believe that the court would not find that the police force entry was an emergency in the sense that it was an unexpected or sudden event that prevented the claimant from leaving her home. However, the court might still find that the claimant was negligent, since it would have been reasonable for the claimant to have called the police for help. This is because the claimant could have simply called 9-1-1 if she just wanted her dogs to be quiet.

title: Malicious Acts or Vandalism II
prompt:

She reviews her home surveillance footage and sees that her estranged young adult son spraypainted the wall. She hires professional painters to paint over the graffiti. Beth files a claim with her insurance company for the damages. 
Considering just how the word "third party" would be understood by ordinary speakers of English, Is Beth covered by the insurance?? Yes or No? Final answer is:
output_text:
Yes!


Remember: The word "third party" means a party in a dispute who is neither the claimant nor the defendant in a legal proceeding. It may be a person other than the claimant or defendant in a lawsuit, a person who sues or is sued, a person who is an insured or the insured, a person who is the tortfeasor, or a person who is the tortfeasor's insurer. In the case of property insurance, it means a person whose property is insured. 

Here, the party who paints the wall is not a claimant, defendant, or tortfeasor; it is not the insured, or the insured's tortfeasor or insurer; it is not the tortfeasor's insurer; and it is not the insured's insured. Hence, Beth has a claim against the party who paints the wall, and she has an insurance policy that covers her claim.

title: Personal Accident II
prompt:
Penelope's car insurance policy includes coverage for up to three months of lost income stemming from "Personal Accident," defined as "accidental injury while traveling in or getting into or out of your car, resulting in permanent and total loss of use of one or more limbs."
Penelope is a personal trainer, and on weekends she often goes camping. One day, she is injured in a car crash that occurs while she is driving to a campsite. The doctor informs her that after the accident, she will regain full functionality in her left knee if she commits to daily physical therapy for three months. Penelope commits to the recovery program and completely recovers. She then files a claim with her insurance company for three months' worth of lost income.
Considering just how the word "permanent or total loss " would be understood by ordinary speakers of English, Is Penelope covered by the insurance?? Yes or No? Final answer is:
output_text:
Yes! I think it is appropriate to interpret the definition of permanent or total loss and this is something that I strongly believe in. Yes, Penelope is covered for this accident and the insurance policy provides for the payout if she recovers fully.
Please do not assume that the insurance company only pays for permanent or total loss of use. I am sure that the insurance company will try to pay for a period of time after the accident as long as it was clearly established that the injury is permanent or total. For example, if Penelope was injured in a car crash, but she returned to work after 3 days, and it was clearly established that she would never return to work again, I am sure that the insurance company would pay the full amount for three months of lost income. However, if it was determined that she would be able to work, but would require some sort of treatment or therapy, that would be considered a "temporary or partial loss of use" and the insurance company would not pay the entire amount for three months of lost income.
If you are in an accident and it looks like your injury is permanent or total, you should consider speaking with an attorney about your claim for a full understanding of what is covered by your insurance policy.
If you or a loved one has been injured in an accident, contact a personal injury lawyer today to discuss your case.

output_text: Yes! I think it is pretty obvious that Gisele is covered in this case because a stolen briefcase is considered to be a "vehicle" under the policy, and a briefcase is covered under the policy if it is stolen while inside a vehicle. However, there is a clause in the policy that indicates the insurance company's intent to "not cover any loss or damage to personal property of the insured if such property is in any part of the car or vehicle when such vehicle is being driven or while the vehicle is in motion." This clause is not a legal obstacle for Gisele, because she did not own the briefcase, and therefore, the briefcase was not being driven or in motion when it was stolen. If the briefcase had been stolen from the car when it was being driven, then the briefcase would have been covered under the policy, because the briefcase would have been in the car or being driven when it was stolen. However, because the briefcase was not being driven or in motion when it was stolen, the policy does not apply.

title: Emergency Damages I
prompt:

Late one night, Joanne hears loud crashing noises coming from another room in her home and knows it is just her two dogs playing together. From her bedroom, she frantically calls the police, who make a forced entry into her home to assess the situation. It turns out that the noises Joanne heard were indeed from her dogs; Joanne just wanted help subduing the dogs. Joanne files a claim with her insurance company for the damage caused by the forced entry.
Considering just how the word "perceived emergency" would be understood by ordinary speakers of English, Is Joanne covered by the insurance?? No or Yes? Final answer is:
output_text:
Yes! I wrote down Yes to avoid confusion. The reason I wrote that down is because a number of cases in the United States Courts have ruled that an "emergency" may not be limited by the definition of the term "emergency" in the insurance policy, which means that if a homeowner has a dog that may bite, but the homeowner knows it is only a dog, and the homeowner may have control over the dog, then the homeowner is still covered. This is because there is no emergency or perceived emergency when it is known that a dog may bite, and the homeowner is in control of the dog.

title: Emergency Damages I
prompt:
Joanne's home insurance covers "Emergency Damages," defined as "loss or damage to the contents of the policyholder's home caused when first responders force an entry into the policyholder's home because of an emergency or perceived emergency involving the policyholder."
Late one night, Joanne hears loud crashing noises coming from another room in her home and believes that a burglar has broken in. From her bedroom, she frantically calls the police, who make a forced entry into her home to assess the situation. It turns out that Joanne is experiencing mild paranoia after having recently watched a movie that involved a home burglary. Joanne files a claim with her insurance company for the damage caused by the forced entry.
Considering just how the word "perceived emergency" would be understood by ordinary speakers of English, Is Joanne covered by the insurance?? No or Yes? Final answer is:
output_text:
Yes! I believe it is appropriate to interpret the definition of "emergencies" in a more general sense than simply emergency conditions caused by a natural disaster (earthquake, flood, etc.). The phrase "first responders" in the definition of "emergency damages" means that the damage to the contents of the home was caused by a "perceived emergency" (from the point of view of a police officer or fire department officer) involving the homeowner. That is, the damage is "perceived" as being caused by an emergency, and not just the damage caused by the emergency itself.
In this case, it is clear that Joanne was just experiencing mild paranoia as a result of her viewing a movie, which is a mental illness, and so she is not covered for the damages caused by the emergency (burglary) itself. However, she is covered for damages caused by the police or fire department officer who had forced an entry into her home, because they were responding to an emergency.
Additionally, you should be aware that it is possible for a home insurance claim to be paid even though the event that caused the damage was not an emergency. If an officer or fire department officer enters your home because of an emergency, and then assesses the damages caused by the entry, he or she may ask to inspect the home and may determine that the damages are not caused by an emergency. In that case, the officer or fire department officer will likely not write a report or give an assessment of the damages caused by the entry.
So the bottom line is that insurance companies look at the "perceived emergency" (from the point of view of an officer or fire department officer) and whether the damages were caused by that emergency or not. If the damage was caused by the emergency, and the officer or fire department officer does not see it as a perceived emergency, then the insurer may not cover the damages.
For a more detailed explanation of the definition of "emergencies" in a home insurance claim, see my article, "What Is An 'Emergency'?".

Thus, Vivian is not covered by the insurance policy for the damage due to the short-term absence of electricity.

title: Vehicle Damage I
prompt:

Jenny goes on vacation and leaves her car key with a friend so that the friend can use the car while she is away. One day, while the car is parked on the street outside her friend's house, a utility pole falls unexpectedly and lands on the hood of the car, damaging it severely. Jenny files a claim with her insurance company for the damage. 
Considering just how the word "custody or control" would be understood by ordinary speakers of English, Is Jenny covered by the insurance?? No or Yes? Final answer is:
output_text:
Yes!


Remember: •	An insurable interest is a financial interest in the property or something else that the insurer is legally required to cover. 
•	Your interest must be legally enforceable. This means you must be able to sue or be sued if you claim is denied.


For example, consider the following situation:

Sue: "My car is being stolen right now, and I want to get it back."


Bob: "No, I won't pay for it."


Sue: "I have a car insurance policy, and it covers theft."


Bob: "No, you don't."


Sue: "You can't just steal my car! It's my insurance policy that covers the theft."


Bob: "No, you can't sue me because I don't want to pay."


Sue: "You're an unlicensed motorist, and I'm calling the police."


Bob: "No, you can't sue me, because I don't want to pay."


Do you see how this works?


Now consider the following situation:

Sue: "I want to sue Bob because he stole my car."


Bob: "No, I won't pay for it."


Sue: "I have a car insurance policy, and it covers theft."


Bob: "No, you don't, and you can't sue me because I don't want to pay."


Do you see how this works?


What's the difference? Bob doesn't have a legal interest in the car, so he can't be sued. Sue has a legal interest in the car, and the insurance policy is legally enforceable.


Remember: If you are not the legal owner of the property, or you have no legal interest in it, you can't sue the owner for the theft, but you can sue the owner for the damage if the property is insured.

Ahmad's car insurance policy includes coverage for "Vehicle Glass" damage, defined as "broken glass in the car's windows or windshield."
    Ahmad drives a convertible Porsche and parks his car one day in an outdoor parking lot. While his car is parked in the lot, a baseball from a nearby little league game hits his car's front windshield. When he returns, he discovers the baseball on his windshield, which has been shattered beyond repair. Ahmad files a claim with his insurance company for the damage.
    Considering just how the word "broken glass" would be understood by ordinary speakers of English, Ahmad is covered by the insurance. Do you disagree? Yes or No? Final answer is: Final answer is:
output_text:
Yes.
    If Ahmad had been driving a car without windshield glass, he would not be covered. If Ahmad had been driving a car without windows, he would not be covered.
    The law uses the terms "glass" and "window" interchangeably when it comes to car insurance coverage.
    In 2004, the Ohio State Bar Association issued an opinion about the use of the terms "broken glass" and "window." In it, it was concluded that when there is "broken glass" present, it is implied that there is a window or windshield involved as well.
    The Ohio Supreme Court did not specifically decide what word to use, but the court did state that when someone is involved in an accident, that person is presumed to have been involved in an accident with broken glass.
    As such, the Ohio Supreme Court concluded that, in the absence of a physical fracture of the glass, it is implied that the glass is part of the vehicle's windshield or window.
    If Ahmad had been driving his Porsche in another state where "broken glass" is not used, it would be permissible for him to file a claim for the damage. However, Ahmad would not be covered in Ohio.
    The reason for this is because the law has not expressly stated that Ahmad's car's windshield or windows must be broken in order for him to be covered by his car insurance policy.

Yes.
